As well as courage, another quality of all these uprisings is people's amazing capacity for self-organization. In short order, they have forged block committees, defended free zones, cleaned up the garbage, tended the wounded, and so on -- in an elaborate division of labour, complete with delegation, trust, coordination, communication and civic responsibility. Remarkably, they have exercised restraint in the treatment of their enemies, the regime's thugs, with a relative absence of revenge beatings that makes these pro-democracy insurgents seem like saints!

Now this is extraordinary; it cannot last. But it shows people's capacity for building civil society institutions from the ground up. That, in turn, is crucial if electoral democracy -- choosing representatives to govern among contending parties -- is to take root. Representative democracy cannot flourish without a dense network of civil society organizations beneath it to enlist citizens in community efforts that give them a sense of responsibility for one another. Capitalism fosters growth and employment, but it does not encourage a strong sense of community -- the caring and sharing that makes citizenship meaningful. In these revolutions, time and again, we have seen masses of people show a capacity and willingness to organize themselves so as to care for one another and assure their community's life-necessities.

I would have to agree with your statement that, "Egypt, Libya and Bahrain are better positioned today for democracy than Mongolia or Indonesia seemed in the 1990s". With the revolution of social networking more and more people have been able to defy this bedouin curtain, akin to the bamboo and iron curtains, that the governments have tried to use to suppress freedom of information.
Where I have to disagree with you is saying that the Arab world is ready for democracy. I don't believe that the citizens of these countries are able to make educated decisions on political issues. I don't wish to generalise, because I do agree with the revolutions that are underway in the Middle East. The question is, once a country ousts its leader, what happens next? That is what we are seeing in Egypt, and undoubtedly in the other countries where revolution is successful. A country in limbo. What this leads to is a leaderless country, which can be picked up and manipulated by a Western "democracy" and the whole process of corruption begins again...
What these countries need is to be educated about proper politics, and only afterwards be allowed to decide what happens with the country. We don't need people to blindly choose a new social order, it is unfair on them.
The Arab world is better positioned for democracy than ever before, but something tells me that they just aren't quite ready for it..

I was convinced that Democracy required a kind of stability, which is seemingly how the preceding commenters have perceived the notion.  Not only that, Democracy is still of a Western origination, which gives more experienced Democracies untold advantages one may label Imperialistic--effectively the opposite of self-sovereignty.  On the other side of the coin, in a globalized context this system, in society yearning for freedom and prosperity, theoretically one is not extremely far-fetched.  Still, a successful democracy has taken 200 years to realize a pluralism it intended in the first Constitution.  I do not think adversion to spreading our system elsewhere is particularly racist, nor patronizing, instead I think it stems from a perhaps overly-protective stance from a nation well-aware of the practical difference in our realm of a safety zone.  Naturally, the Democratic-style would need to be adapted to the customs of the said culture.  That much forewarned, how yet should our thoughts and editorials impede progress, when aside from already having destroyed neighboring countries like Afghanistan, it remains an internal affair for Egyptian leaders and the surrounding entities to modernize peacefully, at least to that extent..  Democracy makes sense, afterall.

Nicolas Kristof wrote: “I’m awed by the courage I see, and it’s condescending and foolish to suggest that people dying for democracy aren’t ready for it.” Thank you for sharing what you saw and experienced in the field. This wave of democratizing movements in middle east also created an opportunity for Western journalists to report the events being embedded with real people. Usually when Western journalists write about Middle East they put on their ideological glass (I’m not blaming them; they developed that frame of reference over time). But the recent protests were so strong, emotional and humanistic that journalists probably could feel it. I know how it would feel if you are a part of millions of people who want a change. No matter how objective you are, you are moved. So, Nicolas, thanks for sharing that feel.
In terms of that debate that Arabs are ready for democracy: yes, even in the overwhelming desire that people in Middle East are showing some people in the United States are rasing that question. Yes, it’s condescending, and I would say, borderline racist. It’s OK if your are skeptical whether democracy would work or how well it work, because you need institutions for the functioning of democracy. Many of the Middle Eastern countries do not have those. But it’s another thing to insinuate that Middle Eastern people are not ready for democracy.

Well, it further seems that this word, which, iconographically, has a reference point to "holy writ" is something which means a great deal (huge numbers of people seem to desire it). Many of those who desire it probably are unsure of what it entails, nevertheless they are not only probably worthy of it, but also capable of it. I think that you are correct that those who maintain otherwise, do so out of a desire to maintain some sort of status quo. Political scientists would maintain the conceit regarding the mysterious division of it into two distinct types, majoritarian and consociational, thus preserving their own sanctity. The bottom line, I think, is that since ancient times (the Greek theocracy) the idea of a bonded society based upon equality for all has always proved to be an illusion not really capable of attainment. Col. Quaddfi did alot for his people. So did the Italian geographers and geologists, British petroleum interests, Aramco, etc. If he, as legitimate head of state of Libya, cannot put down a rebellion, the origin of which seems somewhat obscure, then what does that say about the countries and organizations which oppose his doing so. Do they act  in the interests of those aforementioned entities as though they were creditors foreclosing upon a long-due debt? Or is the answer more pragmatic? Again the question of the peculiar commodity looms large. Maybe he is an anachronism; all this pressure, if it continues, will surely make one of him. Its authoritarian character not only will harm the Libyan people, but also will serve as a miserable starting point for whatever changes can and or will be wrought. This idea of democracy is a hot one, pragmatic, to be sure.

In spite of the rapidly growing concern about the damage of this technology, it has not been addressed enough with the kind of depth in the mainstream press it warrents - and for this article: THANK YOU! This study is seriously timely, as the moratorium on horizontal fracking expires end of June 2011. I hope your study will include much more than the damage of radioactivity, which is substantial. Coverage about the impact of land and air pollution and contamination needs to be in print. There is evidence that toxic chemicals can not be filtered out of the water, and even in parts per billion will cause cancer and birth defects. (We also know that because the killer whales' babies in the Pudget Sound are born with cancer caused by rain run-off on asphalt (fossil fuel and gasoline) roads.) Furthermore, the myth that natural gas is going to get us off foreign oil must be debunked now. When all aspects of drilling are considered, there are studies that show it's carbon emissions level is similar to coal. The gas companies are so eager to drill now - not because we can use it in the US but because they can sell it for a lower price than their competitors abroad. Basically, we taxpayers are funding (by exemptions) their profits.

New York City is pushing to convert boilers to natural gas. Burning radioacative gas... what a bad idea that it!

My hope is that the study the NY Times has done will inspire a deeper understanding of the serious risks of continuing to vertical (now happening in upstate NY) and horizontal hydrofracking.

My hope is that New York would follow the lead of Seville, Spain and other cities in converting to a truly green (non-fossil fuel) energy systems now.

We have the knowledge. We now need to push hard for political will.

What happens to the water used in the mining process is important in the mining of many minerals -- not just natural gas. It is important in oil, gold and uranium mining at least. The first question when a company wants to mine an area, is how much water does it require and what becomes of the water once it has been used in the process.
Here in the arid Southwest we have had to give up many mining projects though they would have enriched us. What good is it to be enriched if one no longer has usable water. Important issue.

The solution is not a new concept. State regulators draft maximum gross alpha radiation effluent standards. State regulators fine treatment plants when those levels are exceeded. Treatment plants are compelled to enforce influent pretreatment standards, shifting the cost onto mining companies. Mining companies get cleaner to save money.

This is what happens when new contaminants need to be managed and it will take about a decade.
